segments.text: Yes, and made apologies for it.
Oh, was anyone killed?
No, no.
No one was killed.
Just a question of a fight.
I don't think there were.
There may have been minor injuries.
I'm not aware.
As I recall, there were no major injuries at any time.
Nobody had to go to the hospital.
And we...
I told him that we were going to the death school with two people involved.
He said that was satisfactory.
We went on back and handled him, and handled him, and handled him, and the court-martialed him, and sent him back to the state.
What was the verdict and punishment?
The punishment was not, was not a gross, a gross sentence.
I think we find one of them, the one that started it, and the other one that gave him a
Did you have to sit on the court martial?
No.
No, I am proven.
Do you think that this was part of, you know, during the mid-1960s, of course, we had a lot of black riots, civil rights movements.
Was that part of this, or did this have an impact on you?
Yes, it did, because this is what this guy told us about the impact it was having over in the States versus what we had there.
And we had integrated everything.
We had no, the only, he said that they would click together, these younger guys, were really the ones
causing them trouble.
They would click together.
And then pretty soon you had a big problem.
They'd get together and congregate together.
And that's what was causing the problem.
What we did was separate them out so that they were really in there and not all put together.
So some of them, they'd separate them as far as the barracks were concerned.
Yes.
Some of them here and now, and all of them help.
But they still go back and get it.
Sure.
Did it decrease the amount of attention?
Yes.
It did lower the attention.
And we tried to, well, just everything was made as equal as we could make it for everyone.
As a matter of fact, my age was covered.
Sorry?
He was helped too.
He was helped?
He was helped.
In what way?
In the talking about conditions.
The way they saw things.
What the problems were.
What did he think of the changes that you made?
He was formed.
And he felt that you were improving morale?
Yes.
That was a major problem?
Oh, in the States, in the Air Force, you know, in all the services.
That was the only incident that you had?
The only incident I had was in the Air Force.
Of course, during this time,
Europe has sort of taken a second place to war in Vietnam, and did- I thought that there was a tremendous buildup in Southeast Asia, and of course a decrease in supplies and troops in Europe.
Did that have an impact on you and the Azores?
I don't think it did, except it slowed down the amount of traffic that's come through.
Several big exercises every year.
Came through.
A lot of deployments.
Rapid deployments.
Sure.
And did you ever have missions or training exercises with the Portuguese?
Yes.
Unless they had a very small air force.
Oh, yes.
They only had C-54 and a couple other small airplanes there.
That's all they had.
The only thing, they were Air City Rescue.
That's all we did.
We practiced Air City Rescue mission.
with that part of the Portuguese Air Force.
And did, I mean, were you ever called in to help them as far as RC rescue?
No.
How were the relations between your men in general on these, or your airmen and your officers and the Portuguese that lived in that area?
There was no tension at all.
The presence of the base there meant a lot to the economy of that island.
It's called the Isle of Tessera, which means the Third Island, and it was a third great island.
not particularly blessed with a lot of good land to raise cows or, I mean, till, much less, and also raise cows.
We had a few cows.
They raised grapes and vegetables.
That's about all.
Now that you are a general and now that you're in a diplomatic position, I would imagine
Well, we had a lot of pressure on the wives at the squadron officer school because we made all the wives participate.
The wives participated in everything.
Well, not everything, all the functions.
We have a, as soon as the athletics were over,
The families would all join together with a section, and then they'd have hamburgers or cook something, and beer, and soft drinks.
Have a big get-together, then we'd have dining in, so the wives would all come to those.
Normal clothes.
We had a big awards night, and all the wives attended.
We had graduation ceremonies.
We did a whole part of that.
And your wife, because you were a commandant, was she sort of formally in charge of the wives who were the instructors and the students?
Yeah.
And in these, or is...
Did you or your wife ever have an opportunity to learn Portuguese?
Yes, we both did.
Oh, did you?
Oh, yeah.
When I left.
Because I noticed you don't have a school here for Portuguese.
Usually they have a school.
Well, we attended school there on the base.
Mm-hmm.
One afternoon a week, every week.
I even gave my farewell address in Portuguese.
I don't know if he understood the word because it all collapsed.
And then the Air Attach said he could understand it.
Vince Bennett, the Air Attach, is a guy we worked through as an ambassador.
He would come over and meet with us periodically.
What do you think of the quality of the Portuguese Air Force and the officers that you have?
The officers were very impressive, Portuguese officers.
Very proud people.
They don't take time in the criticism because they are so proud.
So you never saw a pal on the back of it.
We got to be very close friends.
And he did this here in the States.
No kidding.
So we've been back.
And they had the takeover over there by the socialists.
He was forced to retire.
He's gotten back in since then.
He's been doing certain jobs for the Air Force.
And he's trying to get there.
His retirement reversed, but I don't think he will.
He may have been present with me, but he's very bitter towards me.
I don't know.
He thinks you're back to normal.
Yeah, it seems that way.
What were your feelings in here about the revolution?
It scared me.
The chance of confidence didn't end.
But I don't think the Portuguese are ready for it.
They're just not the type.
I don't believe it.
What do you mean they're not the type?
They're too individual.
They're not going to submit to that type of regime.
I don't believe it.
They're more used to it.
Almost dictatorship.
We were more liable to go for that side.
Very conservative.
But Salazar is still in?
No, Salazar is in.
Well, I know, but was he in when you were there?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah, that's what I meant.
And Salazar.
Did you have an opportunity to meet him?
What did you think of him?
Very impressive person.
Very.
In what way?
He seemed to have command of himself and everything.
Very sure of himself.
I thought he was doing what was best for the country, really.
The feeling it gave me was that he was doing what he thought was best for the country all the time.
He was not an opportunist.
Was he friendly with the Americans?
I don't think we'd been there if we weren't.
Yeah.
Well, let's stop right here for a minute, okay?
Is there anything else about the Azores that we should discuss?
No, I don't think so.
Well, you had a real quick next assignment, Vice Commander, 12th Air Force Base at Bergstrom, which only lasted from October 69 to May 1970.
Why was it so brief?
Usually, what's that, a two-year job?
Well, you have no set tours as a general officer.
You just go when they say and do what they say, and your life's not your own.
I think they needed somebody over in Vietnam in a hurry, because somebody finished up or something, and I went over to finish up the tour.
I was happy to get the opportunity.
At Bergstrom, was it basically a question of hearing, by this time,
We were training pilots.
Our major thrust was training pilots for replacement pilots to go to Vietnam, yes.
Now, because of the difference in that type of war, the jungle warfare versus the regular World War II or Korean War, was there a different emphasis on training?
Well, the emphasis was making them combat-ready in the aircraft to perform the missions that the aircraft was capable of performing.
And then when they went to Vietnam, they were prepared to do whatever was required.
They could do any mission that was required in their particular aircraft.
And most of these aircrafts, of course, were the jet aircrafts, even though we did use prop planes.
By that time, they were all.
The Vietnamese had the props then.
One thing about Vietnam was, of course, the SAM missiles.
Did you train them to attempt to evade SAMs?
Well, you had evasion tactics, yes, that you taught them.
They were given all the tactics for SAM evasion, what to do, and so forth.
What were they told to do?
They had all different.
It depends on the situation.
And if they knew that SAMs were firing, well, they took evasive tactics.
And they were able to maneuver so that they would not be intercepted.
Quite a few, of course, during 67 and 68, when they put SAMs in North Vietnam, quite a few of our fighter pilots were shot down.
How was morale?
Well, morale wasn't...
The morale when I was there was good.
Now, I'm not sure about how it was back when several of them were getting shot down.

But we had perfected electronic countermeasures so that we knew when they were launched and we knew more about where they were because we had ECM aircraft go with the strikes, especially those in the north that not.
They all had
As well as all the B-52 missions, too.
And the training back at Bergstrom was a lot of new technology?
Not a gross amount of new technology.
The training at Bergstrom itself was only for the RF-4, and that was only for the reconnaissance.
So we had the other bases at Luke and Nellis and George and I don't remember.
We had several other bases where we were training people on different types of aircraft.
Now, when you got to Bergson, did you apply for Vietnam?
When you get to be a general officer, you don't apply for anything.
But you must have friends and said, gee, I sure would like to get to Vietnam.
I mean, did you tell anybody that you wanted to get over there because you were next to her duty in June of 1970?
It was in Vietnam.
Yeah.
I was happy to go.
I wanted to go.
As I said before, when you get to be a general officer, you don't ask questions.
You just go where you're told, and if somebody wants you, they'll call for you.
If they don't, they won't.
Okay.
Now... You have no choice in the matter.
Right.
You were at Tan Sonot for the 7th Air Force
And you were in operations.
Yeah.
What exactly was your job?
The job was to direct all the operations of the different organizations that were under Seventh Air Force.
I wrote all the ops orders, tell them what to do, and coordinated with intelligence to send out that information.

and directed the reconnaissance missions to fulfill the intelligence requirements, and evaluated the performance of the units below, and evaluated requirements of what was going to be needed in the future for whatever program that we had, whatever our program was going to be.
in the ongoing year and provide the command and the control for the direction of the commander to direct the operation.
Now, when you were down there,
Was it the responsibility of the 7th Air Force, basically that core area?
No, the responsibility of the 7th Air Force was the responsibility for the whole.
For the whole Vietnamese theater, but not including Thailand.
Including Thailand.
Including Thailand.
Including Thailand.
They're everything in Southeast Asia.
Okay, and Okinawa?
No, not Okinawa.
So who controlled the B-52s?
The B-52s were, we controlled the B-52s, their strikes.
But we only had operational control over them.
Right.
Then you went back to Okinawa.
Yeah.
Okay.
This war, of course, has been debated by historians now for a long time, and was debated by the public at large for a few years, especially when you were there.
And I'd like to ask you some questions about that war.
How did you feel that we were getting along with the South Vietnamese?
Well, we were getting along with the South Vietnamese Air Force fairly well, but I don't think we were getting along too well with the South Vietnamese people.
I think it was a dirty, rotten mess.
It was a no-win war, which is ridiculous.
The situation that we put our forces in, we put our people in, was almost inexcusable.
I just can't see anybody wanting to put the United States of America in that sort of condition.
Why don't you elaborate on that?
Well, when you get in a no-win situation and the President of the United States has to direct a squadron what it can do, then something is wrong.

When you tie the hands of your strike force that could have ended the war in the very beginning, in a short period of time, and you tie their hands so completely that all they can do is what they're told they can do that day by the President of the United States, then there's something lacking.
And we never will win one like that.
That's the second no-win thing we've been through.
And there was no excuse to be in the mother.
And Korea was bad enough, but this Vietnam thing is ridiculous.
It's just a dirty, rotten mess.
That's all I can say.
Okay, now tell me about, give me a specific example of this no-win situation.
We weren't allowed to bomb in North Vietnam.
When I first got there, we couldn't bomb in North Vietnam.
We had to get permission.
It was directed down from above what targets would it hit.
So the Pentagon and the White House controlled...
It was in the White House.
So the White House controlled the targeting.
And that must have caused a lot of resentment in Saigon.
It did.
It caused resentment everywhere.
And I think Mr. Kennedy could have stopped it from the very beginning.
So if you don't withdraw those, we're going to do this tomorrow.
We're going to bomb this factory or this place or this place and then go up and do it.
And if we displayed some power at the very beginning, rather than keeping completely hands off, there never would have been a war in South Korea.
They've been stopped in North Vietnam.
We did the same thing in Korea.
We stopped at the Yalu River.
We didn't go across the Yalu River.
So the Chinese came in and wiped us out.
So as far as China now for a second, did you agree with John MacArthur as far as we should have been bombing north of the Yalu?
Yes, I did.
Of course, I don't disagree with President Truman firing because President Truman was the boss.
And if the boss says do that, you do it.
If you look in retrospect, everybody can look back and see what would have been better and what wouldn't.
Most of them can.
But in my opinion, we would have been a lot better off if we had gone ahead.
They never would have come in, in all probability.
Did you sense a lot of resentment in Saigon with your superiors?
Who was your superior, by the way?
Well, George Brown, who was later chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff,
What are his feelings?
I believe he felt the same way, and General Abrams did too.
And most of the Air Force, the senior Air Force people that I knew felt that way, in my opinion.
Of course, I can't speak for them, but that's the way I felt they thought.
Now, you made an earlier statement that we got along all right with the Air Force Vietnamese people, but we didn't get along all right with the civilian population.
Could you elaborate on that?
Well, I don't know what question of getting along with them, just the stories that were told me about encounters with them.
And the Vietnamese people didn't want us there, I didn't think.
How'd you know?
Out in the boondocks, the people out in the boondocks.
They wanted everybody to go away and leave them alone.
That was the feeling that you got.
That's the feeling I had.
Now, in the... Did you have any examples?
I mean, did you have any good things to tell you then?
I had a chaplain who was in the field with the airborne division tell me that that's where I got the feeling, the expression of that feeling from him, that he got that feeling.
I guess the Vietnamese had been under the French and under domination for so long that they were happy to be away from that, and yet they don't want North Vietnam taking them over.
We were there.
We prolonged the war.
by being there.
Or we could have, if we had done it right in the beginning, they would never have had a chance to come in, in my opinion.
What were the conditions like at Pan Snow?
As far as the Americans were concerned, they were fine.
Comfortable quarters, good flying conditions.
good facilities, good runways, good radar control.
We've got a good system there, a good tactical control system to take care of the strikes, monitoring.
How effective do you think that the Air Force was in Vietnam as far as destroying the enemy?
I mean, on the missions.
Regardless of what the politicians controlled or which ones you could bomb, et cetera, how about the ones that you could?
How effective were they?
I think they were quite effective.
I don't think there's any question about it.
They were very effective.
We were able to hit the targets.
And if the intelligence was good, we clobbered whatever was there.
But when you can't see through the jungle,
We have an impossible problem almost.
Yeah.
To even assess your game.
Sure.
That is a problem, and of course we bombed the Ho Chi Minh Trail to death almost, and we still didn't stop the flow of supply.
I'm surprised.
Is that correct?
That's correct.
Why not?
I don't know.
I really don't know.
We may have stopped the flow, but they already had so many down there, they didn't need them.
And give them time enough to repair and get through.
And don't ever think we didn't bomb it.
We bombed the hell out of it.
Looked like the moon.
What about the Debolian campaign of the ranch hands?
as part of the Air Force.
Is that also under your control?
This, of course, has come into the news lately, Agent Orange, and if that is going to have an impact on the people who were sprayed, et cetera.
And I was wondering about your ideas of the use of the deployments.
Well, I'm not too sure in my own mind how effective it was.
Some people think it was quite effective.
And others, like me, they're not quite so sure.
It had some effect.
I know that.
But to be worth all the effort it took, I don't know whether it was worth it or not.
I just wasn't in a position to evaluate it, really.
What did you think of General Brown?
What's your opinion on him?
He was fine.
Fine.
Fine, outstanding soldier.
A real professional soldier.
How'd you get along with him?
What kind of man is he?
Is he easy along with ours?
Is he demanding?
No, he's fairly demanding, but not overly so.
He just wanted you to do your job.
He was very fair and knew what he wanted.
sure of himself.
He still was very pleasant to me, and will remain in any way.
How'd you, did you, did you know General Abrams?
Yes.
Probably worked pretty close on, on something.
Worked, well I went to his staff meeting every week.
Yeah.
And uh.
How was he?
He, he's a, he was a crusty old soldier.
of the old school.
I admired him.
Why?
I thought he was a great American.
He was very thoughtful of his men.
He took advantage of every bit of intelligence that he could get, and he tried in every way to win the war.
supportive of the Air Force and their mission, and the Navy as well.
He was, I think, just an outstanding commander, really.
He had a grasp of the situation and knew what he was trying to do, and worked at it day and night.
Hard working, man.
I know he was.
In general, then, it sounds to me that you have a very high opinion of the military leadership of the American Forces in Vietnam.
I sure do.
I sure do.
How about on the other side?
How about, let's talk about that.
I know we talked a little bit about how you got along with the Vietnamese.
Air Force people, but, you know, a lot of the blame, I heard a lot of blame put on the Vietnamese themselves for losing their own war, and I'm sure you've heard that.
What's your opinion on that?
Well, I think in a large part that might be true.
I don't know whether they had any anything that brought them all together to really want to do something.
I don't know whether I'd almost call them lethargic.
They didn't want to talk about the peasants out in the field.
They didn't know about all this other stuff going on.
They just wanted everybody to leave and let them alone.
That's the feeling and impression that I got from talking to people.
And did you take, every once in a while, did you take trips out in the field?
Yes, I went to every one of the bases.
I flew missions.
You actually were flying some missions?
Yeah.
What kind of aircraft?
Well, I flew one in the F-100, and I flew one in the F-4.
As a major general?
Yeah.
They had you fly in missions?
Well, they let me fly missions.
Oh, they let you.
But isn't that unusual?
I don't think so.
I flew nine reconnaissance missions.
But you didn't fly any combat, did you?
No.
Yes, I flew combat.
You flew, like you flew into North Vietnam?
Oh no, they were not letting me go into North Vietnam.
I was thinking you would have been captured.
I know it, that's North Vietnam.
So I went on missions in Vietnam, where they were dive bombing missions.
And you participated?
Yes.
I don't know, I just, to me.
It seems incredible that they'd have a major general doing that, not only because of your rank, but also because of your age.
What do you mean my age?
I was combat qualified in the RF-4.
Well, I know that you're combat qualified, but I was under the opinion that mostly on these you'd have the younger men doing these.
You do, but you got to know something about it.
I've always felt that the guy in charge ought to know something about what the guy is asking him to do, what he's asking him to do.
He should know.
Oh, yeah.
But you went out in strafing and dive bombing missions?
Yes.
I wasn't doing it.
I was in the back seat with a guy in the front.
I ain't doing the actual firing.
And that was typical for a major general?
I don't know if it was typical or not.
As I say, there were only three or four missions that I went on.
And I flew the reconnaissance missions.
I was taking pictures.
I actually did those in Cambodia and South Vietnam, and also in Laos.
Not with none, no.
And what did you find out on these missions?
What the problem was, when they were trying to find the tardy in the jungle, and even though you mark it, the forward air controller marks it with smoke, you don't see anything but leaves, trees.
So you go down and hit the smoke and hope there was something there.
Occasionally you get an explosion and know you hit something.
Because you have no idea what you're bombing most of the time.
You can't jump.
Gee, that must have been really difficult to run bombing missions on a night down.
Yes, it was.
And difficult for the pilots.
What do you think about the quality of our pilots over there?
Outstanding.
Oh, they were super.
compare them to our fighter pilots in World War II?
They were much better trained than we were when we got to combat in World War II.
Really?
Oh, yeah.
They're experienced people.
I mean, people, we got over there maybe with 300 hours of flying.
They were there with 3,000 hours of flying.
So there's all the difference in the world in the level of experience.
And the machines were all complicated, too.
Oh, absolutely.
And more of
technical, and more firepower.
Everything has upgraded tremendously.
How could you ever...
I know one of the things that McNamara wanted to do was to sort of quantify the war.
McNamara was stupid, in my opinion.
Well, I want your opinion on McNamara.
I want you to continue on that.
I think he tried to quantify everything and put it in a computer, and you can't do that, in my opinion.
And he wanted commonality in everything.
And that slowed down the procurement of weapons because he wanted Air Force and Navy to have airplanes that were common to be the same thing.
And he lost sight of the fact that you had to have these things now, not programmed in the future.
like he was trying to do.
And he squeezed down on the budget so that even though we were able to do some research and development, he squeezed it down so much that he cut out most of our research and development.
to stay with the state of the art at this time rather than progress.
Well, that's what I think he did.
He stopped the progression in the state of the art.
There's a lot of resentment in the knowledge area about Mackinac.
Yes, there was.
I guess there still is.
I mean, there was Newman.
Did you ever meet him?
Oh, yes.
When he came to Saigon?
No, when he came to Maxwell.
No, I didn't see him inside, no.
When he came to, um, what's it, and you just came in to inspect, he talked to you?
Oh, he talked to the War College, yeah.
Yeah, okay.
And, uh, usually we'd have a little dinner beforehand, and he invited the Commandants.
For me.
Were people friendly toward him?
Oh, yeah.
There was no dislike for the man personally.
No, I don't think so.
I don't recall any.
You can dislike a man.
I mean, not dislike a man personally, but you can dislike what he does.
His policy was still like him, huh?
I've got a lot of friends that I love, but I don't like some of the things they do.
Now back to Vietnam, and did you ever receive a survey from a Brigadier General that served in Vietnam, and later wrote a book about it, and his name was Douglas Kennard?
Kennard?
D-I-N-N-A-R-D. Never did?
He sent a survey out to, I guess there were 168 generals at one time or the other served in Vietnam.
He sent a survey out to these people and asked them questions about why we lost the war and things like that.
You never did receive any of those?
No.
At this time, you made, or right before that, you made Major General.
Can you tell me about that?
Just that I was eligible and got promoted.
Well, you got promoted awfully quickly.
Well, that's a lot easier.
You only competed with a few people there.
second star than it was the first?
Sure.
Less competition.
A lot less.
And was that part of filling the job in Vietnam?
I mean, did you need two stars to do that job?
Was it usually a two-star response going?
Yeah.
But I was promoted before I went.
Yeah, I know that.
Okay.
I was wondering about
Why did we lose the one in Vietnam?
You alluded to some of this.
I like your answer.

Well, because the Air Force's hands were tied at the very beginning and they weren't allowed to go in and destroy the targets and the will to fight in North Vietnam at the very beginning when we had the capability, when we had the force there to do it, and we didn't do it.
We could have had them at the negotiation table a long time ago if we'd started bombing North Vietnam even after it was authorized.
That's the way we got them to the bargaining table.
But we could have won the war before then without having to go to any bargaining table if we'd done just the same thing.
So in other words... And our hands were tied, actually, when we were bombing North Vietnam.
The specific targets were picked by the President.
Sure.
In other words, you blame politicians.
I do.
Okay.
What about the question of reporting back to the Pentagon how successful you were in the armament of the body counts, which were not very accurate, according to the generals I talked to.
You just talked earlier about
shooting in the jungle, how could you, maybe you might see something explode, how could you tell what kind of damage you were doing if you were hitting the targets?
Well, if you're in the jungle, you can.
But we had other targets and we could see them and we could tell if we shot a truck up or... And we had other
techniques, infrared sensors, and so forth.
And we had smart bombs, too.
They could hit whatever we pinpointed them on.
We had a lot of success with that, smart bombs, infrared sensors.
And when they located troops, we could put something on them.
could at least rattle their eardrums and then hit them.
One of the charges that was made by some people was that there was careerism in the military during the war, and that there was
mandatory for an officer's career to get his tour of duty over there, but then the rotation was so fast that often they couldn't serve, often they couldn't do their job very well.
For example, most jobs are rotated in six months, and you were there for six months, and it was the same situation.
Could you learn that job in six months?
Could you learn who your men were?
Could you work efficiently?
Well, I think that's too short a period.
I really do.
